FiTBiT
//feeling anxious
Continuous breathing helps you calm down by focusing on evenly inhaling and exhaling.
Look around and name 3 things you see, hear and 3 parts of your body. It is a mental trick to bring your mind back to the present moment.
Anxiety causes you to hunch over, limiting air supply to your lungs heart so walk with your shoulders out to increase air flow.
Sometimes the causing factor can be something physical, so it is as easy as to move away from the object to prevent it from aggrivating.
Caffeinated drinks increase the heartrate making a person more prone to suffer anxiety.
The smallest amount of meditation can ease the brain and train it to stay in focus which has proven to be very beneficial.
If you feel that your not improving, make sure to call for help or dial 999 for professionals to step in.
//feeling panicked
Practice breathing in through your nose for a count of five, hold it and then breathe out through mouth to prevent hyperventilation.
By recognizing that you’re having a panic attack instead of a heart attack, you can remind yourself that this is temporary, it will pass, and that you’re OK.
Panic attacks can happen in response to fast-paced stimuli. By closing your eyes, it blocks out the stimuli making it easier to focus on breathing.
It is helpful to find a single object to focus all of your attention on during a panic attack to minimise the effects on yourself.
Endorphins keep the blood pumping in exactly the right away. It can help flood our body with endorphins, which can improve your mood.
If the panic attacks are recurrent, professionals will prescribe you with these medicine to prevent the panic attacks.
CBT focuses on determining the thought and behavior patterns responsible for sustaining or causing the panic attacks, you can change the way you think and feel.
//info
Anxiety is a feeling of unease, such as worry or fear, that can be mild or severe.
People with Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD) worry about their every day lives and it makes them feel anxious most days. Are you one of those?
A heart rate of over 100bpm and increased breathing rate
Excessive sweating as a result of the stress response from Anxiety
The need to relieve yourself as a result of the bodies fight or flight response
Fluctuating temperatures with a period of intense hot or cold flashes
A panic attack is the abrupt onset of intense fear or discomfort that reaches a peak within minutes. They can happen all of sudden and can be described as a rush of intense anxiety. Are you one of those?
An erratic heart rate of more than 150bpm with atrial fibrillation.
The arms, legs or hands trembling are a result to the bodies fight-or-flight reaction.
Shortness of breath as a result of not enough air getting into the lungs.
Dizziness because your brain is trying to process all the symptoms occurring to your body.
Extreme fear of something bad happening as the attack escalates, worrying about your safety.
Feeling nauseous as a result of discomfort in the abdominal region during panic.
//low heart rate
For some people, having a low heart rate is not considered dangerous however in others, it can be a sign of Bradycardia.
Bradycardia causes insufficient blood flow to the brain and to the organs surrounding. A low heart rate can compromise your circulation as your heart may not pump fast enough to keep a healthy flow of blood up to your brain and throughout your body. This can cause symptoms such as:
1 Fainting \n
2 Dizziness\n
3 Confusion or Memory problems\n
4 Shortness of Breath\n
5 Fatigue\n
//normal heart rate
A heart rate between 60-100bpm means your heart is perfectly healthy and it is beating at the correct pace with no irregular movements.
Exercise is one of the factors which affect a heart rate as it can increase to 130-150bpm which is normal because the body needs more oxygen to supply the brain and organs. So do not worry if you see a high heart rate when exercising as it is just the bodies automatic response.
//high heart rate
Tachycardia refers to a heart rate that is too fast. A heart rate of more than 100bpm is considered too fast depending on your age and physical health.
Tachycardia starts in the upper chambers of the heart where the electrical signals fire abnormally. This interferes with electrical impulses coming from the sinoatrial (SA) node, so this rapid heartbeat keeps the heart’s chambers from filling completely between beats, which compromises blood flow to the rest of the body. Symptoms include:
1 Lightheadedness \n
2 Chest Pain\n
3 Fainting (syncope)\n
4 Shortness of Breath\n
5 Heart palpitations — a racing and uncomfortable heartbeat\n
Atrial fibrillation is the irregular beating of the heart, often higher than 100bpm, where the heart feels its pounding or fluttering for a few minutes or seconds.
